div1.p: Flannagan submits a paper to The American Magazine's essay contest on the seven greatest Americans and names Carter as the fifth great American for his contributions to public health.

div1.head: Essay: The Seven Greatest Americans, by Roy K. Flannagan, [1923] [Enclosed in C0312026]
div1.opener:
THE SEVEN GREATEST AMERICANS
Contest Editor,
The American Magazine,
New York City.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
A man's greatness is measured by the degree the
future profits by his life.

By this test, George Washington is the first great
American. But for him there would be no America as we know
it, no great democracy in which greatness inherent in both
low and high might find expression.

James Madison, though overshadowed in history, is
the second great American. He was the real author of the
“Virginia Plan” and the preeminent framer of the Constitution.
In the face of popular disapproval and the transcendent
eloquence of Patrick Henry in opposition, his genius and gen-
eralship accomplished its adoption by Virginia, the pivotal
State. Though unimpressive in stature and voice, yet his
voice was the mind and statesmanship but for which constitu-
tional government in America would not have been.

Abraham Lincoln, the savior of that union for which
Washington fought and which Madison confirmed, is the third
American. He cannot be higher because until there has been a
peoples' government strong enough to live there could have been
no Lincoln.

America's principles are worth their cost. Woodrow
Wilson, therefore, who voiced them to acceptance by a war-torn
world, and united the nations in a League destined to bring
peace to all earth where it can flourish forever, is the fourth
great American.

Just as Pasteur by his discoveries gave the key to
health and longer life, so his diciples in this hemisphere who
unlocked the door are among America's greatest. The most
deserving of these is the unassuming scientist, Henry R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service, who is the fifth great American.
His suggestions to the immportal Reed resulted in locating the
cause of yellow fever. Upon him leaned Leonard Wood in Cuba and
Gorgas in Panama. His unremitting fight for years against
malaria in America and the world brings and will continue to
bring health and all its blessings to millions of his fellowmen
heretofore helpless and hopeless.

William James is the sixth, for the lucid record of
his profound though is revolutionizing educational method and
is making old philosophy a new and delightful aid to life,
health and happy human intercourse.

The great inventor, Edison, holds seventh place by
the very usefulness, joy-giving qualities and universality of
of his wonderful devices.

The fields in which these seven men wrought have
known no greater workmen though numbers more versatile have
entered into their labors and some have gained greater reward
div1.closer: Very truly yours, Roy K Flannagan Roy K. Flannagan
